feed.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin

entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
The discourse delves into the implications of an Elliptic Curve Discrete Logarithm Problem (ECDLP) breaker on a modified version of taproot - a Bitcoin protocol upgrade designed to increase privacy and improve transaction efficiency. Specifically, it examines a scenario where this hypothetical ECDLP breaker interacts with a taproot construction that mandates script-path spending and prohibits key-path spending. In traditional taproot mechanics, a user would generate a public key Q by combining a tweaked NUMS internal key P_N with a hash commitment. The concern raised is whether an adversary possessing an ECDLP breaker could exploit this system by deciphering the private key associated with Q without needing to commit to a specific public key beforehand, which is a requirement for creating a valid script-path spend.
This analysis further explores the potential consequences of disabling NUMS (Nothing-Up-My-Sleeve numbers), suggesting such a measure might mitigate the risk posed by an ECDLP breaker in this context. However, the discussion acknowledges that this solution might not significantly alter the security landscape since it presupposes that quantum attackers cannot compromise hash functions - a foundational assumption in much of cryptocurrency security discourse.
The email also contemplates a hypothetical future where advancements in quantum computing could enable efficient preimage attacks on SHA2 hash functions, posing a profound challenge to current cryptographic practices. Such a development would necessitate a reconsideration of security protocols across the board, indicating a shift towards worst-case scenario planning in cryptographic design and implementation strategies.
In essence, the conversation encapsulates a nuanced exploration of potential vulnerabilities within the taproot framework when faced with advanced cryptographic attacks, emphasizing the need for ongoing vigilance and adaptability in securing digital assets against evolving threats.
